content.description:
This is an aesthetic line up the face of the Midway Boulder as seen approaching from the trail. The crux is the first move then the climb eases a bit in difficulty.

 Start matched on the cool sloper hold in the middle of the face. Use a far left foot to pull into a hard lock off and shoot out left to gaston a positive hold. Match then go up and right to a good hold and lock it off to reach the lip.

 A stream runs directly through the landing zone early spring but it was completely dried up by mid May.
content.location: Center face of the Midway Boulder.

content.description: Start on good holds as far right as possible. Traverse left until you can get a heel on and rock to the slopy lip. For extreme lowballs, this one's pretty good.

Ground Up climbs the slab on the right side of the boulder. Start on a big foothold and smear your way up. 

  This problem was cleaned free on the lead. As such, it's still really dirty. It might be a nice little problem when clean.

Green Shoots climbs the arete/corner on the right side of the boulder. Start with your left hand on a cool sloper and your right hand on a hold on the arete. Bring your foot to a big right foothold, bring left hand to a good small crimp, slap right hand to a bump around the corner, and move up and left to topout.

This climbs the blunt prow facing the trail. Start with a cool left sidepull and a fight edge. Lock off to a good slopey hold and navigate the awkward topout. 

  The sit start is a really great-looking project.

This is the boulder midway up the hill, after you've turned onto the Goodrich Rock trail. It's right of the trail and down in a little valley. This is the first real boulder that's visible as you hike up to the Davis Boulders.
